content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "Department," "infraction," "violation," and "Inspector General." The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines terms like "infraction," "violation," "Inspector General," "intelligence community," and "Secretary." The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines terms related to the intelligence community and Secretary. Use of nongovernmental information systems is addressed in Section 3. Employees of the Department must use only Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify to Congress that all employees have access to these systems. The Secretary must certify to Congress that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems within 90 days of the Act's enactment and annually thereafter. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted identifying employees without access and reasons for the lack of access. The Department must submit a report to Congress identifying employees without access to electronic communication systems, reasons for the lack of access, steps taken to provide access, and measures to ensure proper recording and review of work-related electronic communications. The Secretary of State may waive these requirements on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary of State may waive the requirements for electronic communication recording and review on a case-by-case basis for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. All work-related communications must be archived according to the Federal Records Act, and a written justification must be provided to congressional committees. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication requirements for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. Waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. The Secretary may issue multiple waivers if each is consistent with the certification and justification. The Inspector General must ensure accountability within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary may issue multiple waivers under paragraph (3) if consistent with certification and justification. The Inspector General must develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with requirements. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on the responsible employee, date, and description of each violation. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken by the Department in response. This may involve disciplinary actions, criminal referrals, and remedial training for employees involved. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as disciplinary actions, criminal referrals, and remedial training for employees involved. The report must also justify any failure to terminate an employee or request a review by the Federal Bureau of Investigations for multiple security violations in the past 10 years. Additionally, the report is protected under the Privacy Act of 1974 and cannot be made public. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials for training in detecting classified information spillage. Randomized sampling of emails from employees with security clearances is conducted quarterly to detect spillage. The Inspector General audits the use of randomized sampling to detect classified information spillage and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic transmission. The Secretary must demonstrate personal commitment, allocate necessary resources, optimize sharing of classified information, designate a senior agency official, and manage classified information effectively under Executive Order 13526 (2009). The employee receiving retraining must sign a certification confirming they have received training, understand the rules and penalties, and acknowledge the responsibilities involved. Employees receiving retraining must sign a certification confirming they have received training, understand the rules and penalties, acknowledge responsibilities, and agree not to violate any rules. The emergency refresher training is prioritized for employees with Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information clearances. The Secretary must prioritize emergency refresher training for employees with security clearances in a specific order. The Secretary has the authority to delay training for up to 30 days for employees or groups if it is deemed necessary for critical foreign policy interests. The Secretary can delay emergency refresher training for up to 30 days for specific employees or groups if it is necessary for critical foreign policy interests. Applicable rules and procedures include federal statutes and executive orders related to classified information handling. The term "applicable rules and procedures" in this section refers to federal statutes, Executive Order 13526, other executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance or regulations. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program for Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents under the Freedom of Information Act. The Department employees are tasked with identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests and ensuring intelligence community officials can determine the classification status. Additionally, a training program is to be developed for all Department officials on archiving. The Department employees are responsible for identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests and ensuring intelligence community officials can make classification determinations. A training program will be developed for all Department officials on archiving emails and electronic communications in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. Additionally, employees are required to annually certify that they have archived all documents, including emails, as per the guidelines. The Department employees must annually certify that they have archived all documents, including emails, in accordance with relevant laws. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation of the archiving plan and progress in securing information.
